title: 113_hr4254
content: The Act may be cited as the "Vietnam Human Rights Sanctions Act". Congress finds that Vietnam remains a one-party state controlled by the Communist Party, denying citizens the right to change their government. The Department of State reports severe government restrictions on political rights, civil liberties, and corruption in the judicial system. Arbitrary arrest and detention of political activists persist, with at least 35 activists sentenced in 2012. The Government of Vietnam sentenced at least 35 activists in 2012 to a total of 131 years in jail and 27 years of probation for exercising their rights. Vietnam restricts freedoms of opinion, the press, assembly, and association, limits access to the Internet and telecommunication, and continues to limit freedom of religion. Protestant house churches in Vietnam face persecution from the government, with religious leaders often harassed, arrested, or imprisoned for not conforming to government demands. The United States-Vietnam relations offer a chance for human rights dialogue, but progress on human rights issues in Vietnam depends on the US making it clear that such progress is essential for further bilateral enhancements. Sanctions will be imposed on individuals complicit in human rights abuses against Vietnamese nationals or their family members. The President will impose sanctions on individuals complicit in human rights abuses against Vietnamese nationals or their family members, as required by subsection (b) of the Act. The President will impose sanctions on individuals involved in human rights abuses against Vietnamese nationals or their family members. The list of sanctioned individuals will be publicly available and posted on the websites of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of State. The President will consider data from other countries and non-governmental organizations, including those in Vietnam, when preparing the list. Sanctions include a prohibition on entry and admission to the United States for individuals on the list. Sanctions will be imposed on individuals involved in human rights abuses against Vietnamese nationals or their family members. The President will consider data from other countries and non-governmental organizations when preparing the list. Sanctions include a prohibition on entry to the United States and financial restrictions for individuals on the list. The President may authorize exceptions to sanctions to comply with international agreements. Sanctions will cease when Vietnam releases political prisoners and stops violent practices. In this section, Vietnam is urged to stop violence, unlawful detention, torture, and abuse of citizens while engaging in peaceful political activity. It also calls for a transparent investigation into the killings and abuse of political activists, with prosecution of those responsible. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Convention Against Torture" refers to the UN Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. The terms "immigration laws" and "national" are defined in section 101 of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
